t: Job 30
Job’s Present State Is Humiliating
“But*pn now those younger than I mock me, Whose*ln fathers I disdained to put with the dogs of my flock.
Indeed,*ln what good*i was*i the strength of their hands to me? Vigor*ln had perished from them.
From*ln want and famine they are gaunt Who*ln gnaw the dry ground by night in waste and desolation,
Who*ln pluck mallow by the bushes, And*ln whose food is the root of the broom shrub.
They*ln are driven from the community; They*ln shout against them as against*i a thief,
So*ln that they dwell in dreadful valleys, In*ln holes of the earth and of the rocks.
Among*ln the bushes they cry out; Under*ln the nettles they are gathered together.
Fools,*ln even those without a name, They*ln were scourged from the land.
“And*ln now I have become their taunt, I*ln have even become a byword to them.
They*ln abhor me and*i stand aloof from me, And*ln they do not refrain from spitting at my face.
Because*ln He has loosed His bowstring and afflicted me, They*ln have cast off the bridle before me.
On*ln the right hand their brood arises; They*ln thrust aside my feet and build up against me their ways of destruction.
They*ln break up my path, They*ln profit from my destruction; No*ln one restrains them.
As*ln through*i a wide breach they come, Amid*ln the tempest they roll on.
Terrors*ln are turned against me; They*ln pursue my honor as the wind, And*ln my prosperity has passed away like a cloud.
“And*ln now my soul is poured out within me; Days*ln of affliction have seized me.
At*ln night it pierces my bones within me, And*ln my gnawing pains*i take no rest.
By*ln a great force my garment is distorted; It*ln binds me about as the collar of my coat.
He*ln has cast me into the mire, And*ln I have become like dust and ashes.
I*ln cry out to You for help, but You do not answer me; I*ln stand up, and You turn Your attention against me.
You*ln have become cruel to me; With*ln the might of Your hand You persecute me.
You*ln lift me up to the wind and*i cause me to ride; And*ln You dissolve me in a storm.
For*ln I know that You will bring me to death And*ln to the house of meeting for all living.
“Yet*ln does not one in a heap of ruins stretch out his*i hand, Or*ln in his disaster therefore cry out for help?
Have*ln I not wept for the one whose life is hard? Was*ln not my soul grieved for the needy?
When*ln I expected good, then evil came; When*ln I waited for light, then darkness came.
I*ln am seething within and cannot relax; Days*ln of affliction confront me.
I*ln go about mourning without comfort; I*ln stand up in the assembly and*i cry out for help.
I*ln have become a brother to jackals And*ln a companion of ostriches.
My*ln skin turns black on me, And*ln my bones burn with fever.
Therefore*ln my harp is turned to mourning, And*ln my flute to the sound of those who weep.
